answers: base 60 [or sexagesimal]
lunar month [prompt on month]
epilepsy <The above question is for the category History World and was written by Conor Thompson>
parts: The Babylonians had a number system with this base, which allowed them to do calculations more easily, because this number is divisible by many factors, including the first six integers.

The Babylonian scientist Kidinnu worked to develop the System B calendar, which was based on this unit of time. Hillel II used Kidinnu’s value for the length of this unit of time for the Hebrew calendar.

Esagil-kin-apli’s Diagnostic Handbook contained descriptions of several varieties of this disease, which it attributed to possession by spirits and prescribed spiritual treatments for. This condition was the subject of Hippocrates’s On the Sacred Disease.

answers: lamassu (LAH-mah-soo)
bull [prompt on cattle; prompt on cow]
Pazuzu <The above question is for the category RMP Non-Greek/Roman Myth and was written by Penelope Ashe>
parts: Name these four-legged, winged, human-faced guardians frequently sculpted at the entrance to Assyrian palaces.
The lamassu have bodies of this animal. The killing of this animal was a central image of the Mithras cult.
Another winged being in Mesopotamian myth was this wind demon who brought storms and drought from the southwest.

answers: Kara Elizabeth Walker
sphinxes
Andy Warhol <The above question is for the category Arts Sculpture and was written by Shan Kothari>
parts: Name this African-American artist who depicts the violent history of American slavery and racism through room-size tableaux of black paper silhouettes.

Domino donated eighty tons of sugar for Walker’s A Subtlety, which is an enormous sculpture of this kind of mythical creature in front of the former Domino Refinery in Brooklyn. This creature interrogated Oedipus.
Walker was influenced by this artist, whose sculptural installations include Silver Clouds, which is made of helium-filled Mylar balloons. He directed the films Empire and Chelsea Girls.

answers: leatherback sea turtles [or lute turtles; or leathery turtles; or luths]
myoglobin [do not accept “hemoglobin”]
countershading [or word forms; or Thayer’s law] <The above question is for the category Science Biology and was written by Fred Morlan>
parts: Name this type of sea turtle that uniquely lacks a bony shell.
Leatherback sea turtles are able to dive deeper than a kilometer; biologically, they’re able to do so because they have a lot of this oxygen-binding protein. It is found in muscle.
The belly of leatherback sea turtles is a lighter color than their shell, which gives it this kind of camouflage that is also seen in certain sharks.

answers: Red Sammy Butts
Flannery O’Connor
“A&P” <The above question is for the category Literature American and was written by John Marvin>
parts: Name this barbecue proprietor with a pet gray monkey, who runs an institution known as “The Tower” and tells a visiting family about “the Misfit.”
Red Sammy appears in the short story “A Good Man is Hard to Find” by this author. She also wrote “Everything That Rises Must Converge” and the novel Wise Blood.

A cashier named Sammy features in this short story, where he is captivated when “three girls in nothing but bathing suits” enter his workplace. In this John Updike story, Sammy quits his job to defend the girls, and his “stomach kind of fell as I felt how hard the world was going to be.”

answers: continuum hypothesis [prompt on CH]
alef [or aleph; or alef-null; or alef-zero]
power set of A [or 2 to the A] <The above question is for the category Science Math and was written by Jonah Greenthal>
parts: Name this statement that there is no infinite set larger than the natural numbers but smaller than the real numbers.
This Hebrew letter, followed by a subscript zero, is used for the cardinality of the natural numbers.
The generalized continuum hypothesis is that for any infinite set A, there is no set whose cardinality is between the cardinality of A and the cardinality of this set derived from A.

answers: Solinus
The Comedy of Errors
Dromio <The above question is for the category Literature Shakespeare and was written by Fred Morlan>
parts: Name this Duke of Ephesus who punishes Egeon of Syracuse for entering his city.
Solinus and twin brothers named Antipholus (an-TIFF-uh-luss) are characters in this Shakespeare play.
The Comedy of Errors features another set of two characters with this name, who serve the Antipholuses.

answers: Linotype (LINE-oh-type) machine
Baltimore, Maryland [accept The Baltimore Sun]
typewriter <The above question is for the category History American (1865-1945) and was written by Daoud Jackson>
parts: Name the machine invented by Ottmar Mergenthaler that set complete lines of texts in blocks called slugs. This invention sped up the typesetting process, allowing newspapers to get longer.
Mergenthaler based his company in this city. H. L. Mencken covered the Scopes Monkey trial while working for a newspaper based in this city.

James Clephane, who was instrumental in the foundation of the Mergenthaler Linotype company, served as an expert stenographer. His enthusiasm for rapid transcription drove the invention of these devices, the Scholes and Glidden type of which was the first machine that used the QWERTY (quirt-ee) keyboard layout.

answers: an-Nisāʼ [or the women]
hijab
Maryam [or Mary] <The above question is for the category RMP Non-Christian/Bible Religion and was written by John Marvin>
parts: Name this fourth surah of the Qur’an, whose controversial thirty-fourth verse has been criticized for inciting domestic violence.

Many Muslim women wear this veil in a public setting, which covers the head and is supposed to uphold a standard of modesty. It is not mentioned in a sartorial context in the Qur’an, but is extensively elaborated in the hadith.
This woman, the eponymous subject of the nineteenth surah, gave birth to an important prophet under a date palm tree.

answers: labor economics
Marianne Bertrand AND Sendhil Mullainathan [accept in either order]
Chicago [or Chicago School of Economics] <The above question is for the category Social Science Economics and was written by Kurtis Droge>
parts: Name this field of economics, in which, on the micro level, agents must choose between consumption and leisure.

These two researchers found that callback rates were higher for résumés with white-sounding names than for those with black-sounding names in their paper “Are Emily and Greg More Employable than Lakisha and Jamal?”

Bertrand and Mullainathan’s research involved sending résumés to Boston and this Midwestern city. A school of economics in this city included George Stigler, who pioneered the use of search theory in labor economics.

answers: glaciers
plucking [or word forms; or quarrying or word forms]
glacial buzzsaw hypothesis <The above question is for the category Science Earth Science and was written by Fred Morlan>
parts: Name this source of erosion.
This method of glacial erosion is when glacier’s ice is frozen into the rock beneath it. Pieces of that rock are broken off via thawing and refreezing.
This theory posits that glaciers are the limiting force of the height of mountains.

answers: Tangier [or Tangiers or Tanjah]
Gibraltar
Calais (kal-AY or KAL-ay) <The above question is for the category History European 1400-1914 and was written by Nitin Rao>
parts: Name this city that was ceded along with Bombay to Britain as part of Catherine of Braganza’s dowry on her marriage to Charles II. The English withdrew from this city after it was captured by the Alaouite Dynasty in 1684.

This territory separated from Tangier by its namesake strait was captured by George Rooke during the War of Spanish Succession. As one of the Pillars of Hercules, this town’s Rock is represented on the coat of arms of Spain.

This Channel port fell under English rule after the Battle of Crécy (kray-SEE) and became a center for the wool trade. Francis, Duke of Guise (gheez) finally evicted the English from the mainland by taking this city in 1558.

answers: Simplicius Simplicissimus [or The Adventurous Simplicissimus or Simplicissimus or Der abenteuerliche Simplicissimus]
Bertolt Brecht
goat <The above question is for the category Literature European and was written by Daoud Jackson>
parts: Name this novel partly inspired by the life of its author Hans Jakob Christoffel von Grimelhausen’s experience in the Thirty Years War. Its protagonist’s full name is an anagram of von Grimelhausen’s full name.

Grimelhausen’s Simplicissimus inspired this other German’s portrayal of the Thirty Years War in his play Mother Courage and Her Children. This playwright described “Alienation Effects in Chinese Theatre” in an essay.
Swedish soldiers get one of these animals to lick Simplicissimus’s feet to reveal where he has hidden his treasure. One of these animals named Djali is able to spell in The Hunchback of Notre-Dame.

answers: the Old Man of the Mountain [prompt on The Great Stone Face; prompt on The Profile]
North Carolina
Sleeping Giant <The above question is for the category Geography US and was written by John Marvin>
parts: Name this rock formation in Franconia Notch, nicknamed for its resemblance to a human face. Despite collapsing in 2003, it remains the state emblem and a prominent symbol of New Hampshire.

Grandfather Mountain, in this state, is named for its resemblance to a reclining man. It is one of the Blue Ridge Mountains in the westernmost part of this state, whose easternmost region is the Outer Banks barrier islands.

This land formation on the Canadian side of Lake Superior is named for its resemblance to the legendary Ojibwe (oh-JIB-way) figure Nanabijou (nah-nah-bo-ZHOH). It shares its name with a traprock mountain north of New Haven, Connecticut.

answers: F. R. Leavis [or Frank Raymond Leavis]
New Criticism
T. S. Eliot [or Thomas Stearns Eliot] <The above question is for the category Literature British Non-Shakespeare and was written by Shan Kothari>
parts: Name this English critic who put forth Jane Austen and Henry James as representatives of morally serious literature in The Great Tradition. He was known for his strenuous dogmatism as the long-time principal editor of the journal Scrutiny.

Leavis’s formalist emphasis on “the words on the page” is often compared with this school of American criticism whose name was coined in a book by John Crowe Ransom. It emphasized self-contained close reading of poetry.

Other major influences on the New Critics included this man, who included “Tradition and the Individual Talent” and “Hamlet and His Problems” in The Sacred Wood. Leavis particularly admired this man’s poem The Waste Land.

answers: Black Reconstruction in America
W. E. B. Du Bois [or William Edward Burghardt Du Bois]
The Crisis <The above question is for the category History American (1865-1945) and was written by Shan Kothari>
parts: Name this book that applied Marxist analysis to the years after the Civil War. It argued that elite planters turned the white working class against black freedmen through the “psychological wages” of whiteness.
This thinker rebutted the Dunning School in his Black Reconstruction in America. He opposed Booker T. Washington’s Atlanta compromise and wrote The Souls of Black Folk.
In 1910, Du Bois became the first editor of this official magazine of the NAACP. Jessie Redmon Fauset promoted the Harlem Renaissance as literary editor for this magazine.

answers: Camille Saint-Saëns (kuh-MEE san-SAWNS)
xylophone [do not accept or prompt on “marimba” or “vibraphone”]
scordatura <The above question is for the category Arts Music and was written by Penelope Ashe>
parts: Name this conservative French Romantic composer of the opera Samson et Dalila.

Saint-Saëns used this wooden pitched percussion instrument to represent skeletons dancing in his Danse macabre (donce muh-KOB). He used these instruments to parody his Danse macabre in the “Fossils” movement of The Carnival of the Animals.
In Danse macabre, Saint-Saëns has the violin use this technique, by tuning the E string to E-flat.

answers: quus (kwoose)
Saul Kripke [Saul Aaron Kripke]
Ludwig Wittgenstein (VIT-gun-shtyne) [Ludwig Josef Johann Wittgenstein] <The above question is for the category RMP Philosophy and was written by Young Lee>
parts: Name this function that a philosopher used in an example of another philosopher’s rule-following paradox. In that example, this function is confused with addition when someone is asked to add 68 to 57.

This philosopher used the quus function in an example of the rule-following paradox in his reading of Philosophical Investigations. This American philosopher introduced the term “rigid designator” in his book Naming and Necessity.
Philosophical Investigations is by this Austrian philosopher. His Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus ends with the declaration that “whereof one cannot speak, thereof one must be silent.”

answers: associated Legendre polynomials [prompt on Legendre polynomials]
quantum harmonic oscillator [or QHO]
sine <The above question is for the category Science Physics and was written by Joseph Krol>
parts: Name this class of polynomials. They are key to the solution of Schrödinger’s equation in spherical coordinates, since when multiplied by e to the i-m-phi, they form the spherical harmonics.

The related Hermite (air-MEET) polynomials play a key role in quantum mechanics, since they appear in the eigenstates of this system. This system is characterized by a potential V that is proportional to x-squared.

Solving the “particle in a box” system, with endpoints at x equals zero and x equals a, requires no polynomials at all. Instead, all solutions are proportional to this simple trigonometric function of n-pi-x over a for some n, since this trigonometric function has its roots at 0, pi, 2 pi, 3 pi, and so on.

answers: William Hogarth
A Rake’s Progress
asylum [or mental hospital] <The above question is for the category Arts Painting and was written by John Marvin>
parts: Name this artist of The Painter and his Pug, whose serpentine “Line of Beauty” appears on a palette in that painting.
Hogarth’s moralistic series include Marriage-a-la-Mode and this set of paintings, which follows Tom, the hedonistic son of a merchant.

In the last scene of A Rake’s Progress, Thomas is in one of these institutions. Though it seems unusual to a contemporary audience, the well-dressed women visiting this place as a social occasion are not uncharacteristic of the time.

answers: Harvey Bernard Milk
San Francisco
Anita Jane Bryant <The above question is for the category History American (1945-present) and was written by Mike Cheyne>
parts: Name this California city supervisor who was killed by fellow supervisor, Dan White, whose lawyers utilized the so-called “Twinkie defense” to successfully earn a lesser conviction.
In 1977, Milk became the first openly gay man elected to this California city’s Board of Supervisors.

Milk opposed anti-gay laws in California such as the proposed Briggs Initiative. Such laws built off of the successful 1977 campaign in Florida repealing an anti-discrimination law led by this Christian activist and former pop singer.
